U-Report is an online portal that allows young people to register and engage from countries where national U-Report initiatives do not exist. Through this additional online architecture, young people can now join from anywhere and speak out on issues that cross borders. The platform has been live since late June 2015 and also acts as a portal for all national U-Report platforms, helping to extend their reach and impact. The data shows the number of registered users on the U-Report platform globally.

U-Report is a mobile-based system that allows young people to speak out on issues that matter to them. In addition to voice amplification, U-Report fills the significant need for real-time information that can be used to strengthen essential service delivery and hold government and development partners accountable. U-Report was launched in Burundi in early 2014 and users are engaged in regular reporting within their communities. With support from the Innovation Fund, eight province-level multi-partner teams have been established and trained in U-Report and project planning. These teams will mobilise U-Report engagement at province level including through coordination and delivery of public launch activities. The data shows the number of users in Burundi who are currently registered to use U-Report.

Strengthening access to information in real time offers one of the most important opportunities to empower youth, girls and women, reducing then disparities and better answers to their needs. The launch of U-Report in Burkina Faso will enable young Burkinabé to impact the changing social and political context; empower girls and women to cope with harmful traditional practices, improve key familial practices, be better informed about issues like safe pregnancy and good maternal and new-born health. U-Report in Burkina has resulted in youth gathering regularly to discuss and to share relevant ideas to address pressing issues for them.

A tripartite partnership between Digicel Foundation, UNICEF Papua New Guinea and the National Department of Health (NDoH) is contributing towards the target of elimination of new HIV infections among children by 2015. Using RapidPro, this pilot project aimed to increase the number of women and children living with HIV who receive treatment and care; reduce loss to follow-up; improve referrals to maternal and child health services and those related to prevention of parent to child transmission; strengthen ante-natal care for all pregnant women and support supply chain management.

Mexico was the first country to launch U-Report in Latin America. UNICEF Mexico launched the first digital version of U-Report in partnership with The Mexican Youth Institute. SMS will be introduced at a later date, but the platform has been operated over Twitter (@UreportMexico).

UNICEF Chile is rolling out U-Report through Twitter and SMS to engage young people in a range of key issues. In its first phase, issues prioritised by young people themselves are addressed -including sexual and reproductive health and teen suicide. Eventually U-Report will be used to engage young people in national policy development processes, linked to for instance the Constitution and the new Law on Education. U-Report Chile is positioned in partnership with The Ministry of Health, the National Youth Institute as well as local civil society organisations.

UNICEF China has been building out an Innovation Labs in partnership with Tsinghua University. The Lab brought together young entrepreneurs to develop open source technology solutions through a Youth Innovation Forum.
UNICEF Indonesia organised a challenge with local university partners to engage students to develop solutions for challenges facing children in Indonesia.

UNICEF Innovation explored whether Vojo is suitable to support youth participatory initiatives in South Africa, and  what changes would need to be made to the technology in order to improve its relevance in a South African youth context. Vojo is a mobile-phone based storytelling application that allows users from all over the world to share and post stories about their lives, situations, challenges and triumphs through voice messages, SMS and MMS. It can also be used via landline phone for those who do not have access to a mobile phone. The pilot's finding confirmed that Vojo had the potential as a tool to increase youth engagement through an additional channel, provided adaptations were made to suit the context and specific needs of young people
Yuudee App for Children with Autism

Yuudee is an augmentative and alternative communication tool for children who have difficulty in speech and can also be used as a teaching tool for parents and teachers to teach children communication and cognitive skills. Children can press an icon and the App will “speak” out a short sentence or phrase that expresses a need, request, emotion or answer. A built-in repository of more than 400 icons is available for users as a start. Parents and teachers can easily add to these resources and customize lessons catering to the specific needs of each child, with flexible and user-friendly customization functions supported by Yuudee. Development of the Android version and translation of the app into English will be completed to facilitate future scale-up.

Myanmar is undergoing transition at a tremendous pace. Changes are demanding new and different ways of thinking and doing things while presenting a unique opportunity to cultivate the skills and experiences required to successfully engage in this new context. For UNICEF, this changing context meant new opportunities and challenges to meaningfully engage young people as active citizens. One step in addressing this challenge was to embark on the establishment of the Myanmar Social Innovation Lab. The Lab, the first of its kind in Myanmar, brings together a number of partners with a focus on research, outreach and training, and solution design.
Point-of-care Diagnostics for Women and Children

Point-of-care diagnostics bring diagnostic testing using samples such as saliva, urine or blood, directly to the patient. Innovating test strips that provide a diagnosis within 20 minutes for multiple related tests, patients can receive low-cost tests in situ and get immediate results, eliminating loss to follow up and reducing costs of labs, expensive equipment, highly-trained technicians and required infrastructure. Using tools such as a cellphone camera in diagnosis increases accuracy, allowing immediate clinical management decisions to be taken, and appropriate patient care to begin.

UNICEF Uganda has been supporting the development and deployment of U-Portal, a digital content management tool, in schools and youth centres. The existing Drupal-based backend to the Khan Academy Lite framework, developed by the Foundation for Learning Equality, will be upgraded. A leader in the area of open educational resources and open source software will be supported through this project. This upgrade will also ensure that U-Portal is robust and can be deployed in a variety of settings. It will enable the reuse of the current U-Portal frontend, which was developed by Designers without Borders in Uganda via a collaborative, user-focused design process involving young people. With this upgrade, the platform has the potential to serve as a go-to tool for UNICEF Country Offices and partners seeking a flexible, highly usable platform for digital content.

To ensure standards of care are met and children are less exposed to risks, UNICEF supports the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans and Youth to improve the inspection process of residential care institutions. Currently, the system faces a number of bottlenecks that adversely affect response time and the quality decisions after the inspection has taken place. The paper-based process is complicated and long. No real-time feedback loop is currently available to provide results on site to institutions. The Innovation Fund is investing in a new solution to simplify and convert the paper based inspection to a digital form by using a tablet and Open Data Kit software.

National assessments indicate poor learning achievements in students, with major disparities between the capital city and other islands of the Maldives. The Maldives face challenges related to training and further development of teachers' skills. UNICEF Maldives is piloting a e-learning platform to deliver large volumes of content to educators across the country. When this e-learning platform is established, it will reach approximately 4,000 teachers across 200 islands, serving 220 schools. This will be translated into enhanced quality of teaching, which will lead to better learning outcomes in students.

U-Report Brazil will support collection of real-time data from young people and provide them with critical information. The priority issues that U-Report will engage young people on, include collecting data on the effects of the Zika virus on communities and to disseminate information on prevention practices. U-Report will also be used to ensure that young people are involved in the development of the new national base curriculum. Overall, U-Report will help align national with local and regional issues and campaigns carried out through over 800 youth networks spread through the most vulnerable communities in far-away communities and urban centres. U-Report will strengthen analysis and recommendations developed by young people to lower the number of african-descendant youth deaths; and legitimise the voice of youth networks that advocate for racial and diversity rights by adding value to their off-line campaigns.

Syria is the first country to pilot the U-Report app and engage young people through this new channel. U-Report will play an important role in engaging young people and communities in an emergency context, by collecting data on behaviour change and effectiveness of programmes related to various issues. Priority areas include an increase in immunisation rates, enhancing school enrollment among internally displaced children and increasing the number of children accessing child-friendly spaces.

U-Report Guatemala will serve as the main platform for adolescents to link on-going advocacy activities at local level with national policies, including on issues around child marriage, adolescent pregnancy and sexual violence against girls. In 2015 a decree was approved that allows judges to permit 16-year-old adolescents to get married under exceptional circumstances. U-Report will be used to monitor awareness among judges of related laws and their implementain. Data will be share with the Supreme Court and Ministries and Institutions responsible for implementation of relevant laws and policies.
